A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
A purely inseparable extension is a field extension where the minimal polynomial of any element in the extension has a single root, which is repeated according to the degree of the polynomial.
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Purely Inseparable Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of a purely inseparable extension involves the properties of field extensions and minimal polynomials. In the context of field theory, a field is inherently a commutative ring under addition and multiplication. This means that the commutative law (i.e., $ab = ba$ for all $a, b$ in the field) is already a fundamental property of the fields being discussed when defining a purely inseparable extension.\n\nTherefore, the definition of a purely inseparable extension does not require the explicit definition of the commutative law, as the commutativity of the field operations is a given in the context of field theory. The focus of the definition of a purely inseparable extension is on the nature of the roots of the minimal polynomials, not on the commutativity of the operations in the field, which is assumed.
